messages.content: recommend how to name files (use of spaces or . - etc...)

When naming files, it is important to use a naming convention that makes it clear what the file contains, and makes it easy to identify the file. Here are some recommendations for naming files:

1. Use descriptive names: Use names that accurately describe what the file contains. For example, if you are working with a dataset of customer orders, you might name files "customer\_order\_2022-01-01.csv" or "customer\_order\_2022-01-01\_all.xlsx".
2. Use standard file extensions: Use standard file extensions that are widely recognized and understood by computers. For example, ".csv" for CSV files, ".xlsx" for Excel files, and ".xls" for older Excel files.
3. Use lowercase letters: Use all lowercase letters for the file name, including letters that are part of the file extension.
4. Avoid spaces: Avoid using spaces in the file name. Instead, use underscores or other characters to separate words in the name. For example, "customer\_order\_2022-01-01\_all.xlsx".
5. Use a consistent naming convention: Use a consistent naming convention for all files in a project. This will make it easy to identify and locate files, and will make it clear how files relate to each other.

Overall, the goal is to use a naming convention that is clear, consistent, and easy to understand. By following these recommendations, you can make it easier to locate and manage files in your project.
are there any standards in file naming

Yes, there are standards for file naming that can help make it easier to identify and locate files. Here are some of the most commonly used standards:

1. ISO 9660: This is a standard for the organization and naming of files on CD-ROM and other optical media. It defines a hierarchical file structure, and specifies rules for naming files and folders.
2. Windows file naming conventions: Windows uses a set of conventions for naming files. For example, it uses a ".\" prefix to indicate that a file is located in the same directory, and it uses "\_" to indicate a hidden file.
3. UNIX file naming conventions: UNIX uses a set of conventions for naming files. For example, it uses a "/" prefix to indicate that a file is located in the root directory, and it uses "\*" to indicate a directory.
4. Java naming conventions: Java uses a set of conventions for naming classes and methods. For example, it uses lowercase letters, underscores to separate words, and camelCase to indicate the names of variables and methods.

Overall, using a standard file naming convention can make it easier to identify and locate files, and can help ensure that files are named consistently across different systems and platforms. However, it is important to choose a naming convention that is appropriate for the specific needs of your project.
list most important points of iso 9660

ISO 9660 is a standard for the organization and naming of files on CD-ROM and other optical media. Here are some of the most important points of ISO 9660:

1. File format: ISO 9660 defines a hierarchical file structure, with files and directories organized into a tree-like structure. It uses a flat file system, which means that all files and directories are stored in a single file.
2. File naming: ISO 9660 specifies rules for naming files and directories. For example, it uses a dot (".") to indicate the current directory, and underscores ("_") to separate words in a file name.
3. File organization: ISO 9660 defines the structure of a file system, including the location of directories, files, and other metadata. It also specifies the use of a directory entry block (DEB) to store metadata about files and directories.
4. File system structure: ISO 9660 specifies the structure of a file system, including the use of directories, files, and other metadata. It also allows for the definition of "reserved" or "special" areas of the file system, which can be used to store additional metadata or to provide compatibility with other file systems.
5. File permissions: ISO 9660 specifies a set of file permissions that can be used to control access to files and directories. It also allows for the definition of "root" and "superuser" accounts, which have special privileges.

Overall, ISO 9660 is a comprehensive standard that provides a consistent way to organize and name files on CD-ROM and other optical media. It is widely used in the industry, and is supported by many operating systems and applications.

In ISO 9660, file naming is specified using a hierarchical structure that consists of a root directory, one or more directories, and one or more files. Here are some key points to consider when naming files in ISO 9660:

1. File name: The file name is the name of the file, and is stored in the directory entry block (DEB) of the file system. It is a sequence of characters that is up to 8 characters long and consists of one or more words separated by underscores ("_").
2. File type: The file type is specified using a code that is up to two characters long and is stored in the "type code" field of the DEB. The code is used to indicate the type of file, such as "text", "binary", "directory", or "reserved".
3. File name extension: The file name extension is the last part of the file name after the last character of the file name. It is a single character that specifies the type of file, such as ".txt" for text files, ".jpg" for image files, and so on.
4. File system level: The file name is assigned a file system level, which indicates the level of the file system where the file is located. For example, the root directory is at level 0, and directories and files are at levels 1 and 2.
5. File size: The file size is the number of bytes in the file, and is stored in the "file size" field of the DEB. This is used to indicate the size of the file and to determine how much space is available on the file system.

Overall, file naming in ISO 9660 is specified using a hierarchical structure that consists of a root directory, one or more directories, and one or more files. The file name, file type, file name extension, file system level, and file size are all important elements of the file name that are used to identify and locate files on a file system.

Here are ten examples of recommended standardized file names for an office:

1. Invoice\_2022-01-01.pdf: This is a PDF file containing an invoice for the year 2022.
2. Order\_2022-01-01\_all.xlsx: This is an Excel file containing customer orders for the year 2022.
3. Purchase\_2022-01-01\_all.csv: This is a CSV file containing a list of purchases for the year 2022.
4. Payroll\_2022-01-01\_all.xlsx: This is an Excel file containing payroll records for the year 2022.
5. Employee\_2022-01-01\_all.txt: This is a text file containing a list of all employees for the year 2022.
6. Expense\_2022-01-01\_all.xlsx: This is an Excel file containing all expenses for the year 2022.
7. Inventory\_2022-01-01\_all.csv: This is a CSV file containing a list of all inventory items for the year 2022.
8. Tax\_2022-01-01\_all.xlsx: This is an Excel file containing all tax records for the year 2022.
9. Budget\_2022-01-01\_all.xlsx: This is an Excel file containing all budget records for the year 2022.
10. Financial\_2022-01-01\_all.txt: This is a text file containing a summary of all financial transactions for the year 2022.
